image.altText: A composite image of James Rose and Stephen Gale.

props.synopsis: Police say they have found the fuselage of a plane which crashed into Port Phillip bay on Sunday. The wreckage will be removed from the water and searched.

title.children: Wreckage of plane that crashed in Melbourne's Port Phillip bay found, police say

subjects.title: Air and Space Accidents and Incidents

image.altText: Woman in a black dress with printed white florals wearing sunglasses, standing on a street.

props.synopsis: A youth worker says a 12-year-old girl charged with the murder of a 37-year-old woman in Melbourne last week was failed by the system that should have been looking after her.

title.children: Footscray locals say 12yo girl charged with murder was failed by authorities

image.altText: Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin sits at a desk in front of a microphone at a Senate inquiry.

props.synopsis: Questioning what benefit the resignation of Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin will have, Australia's first national anti-corruption commissioner warns a "blame culture" has led to scapegoating leaders for mistakes, rather than focusing on fixing problems.

title.children: 'Blame culture' behind Optus chief's resignation, warns anti-corruption commissioner

image.altText: Emma Walters wearing a floral pant suit leaving court with her legal representatives.

props.synopsis: A secret recording played in court reveals Emma Walters, the estranged wife of union figure John Setka, told a private investigator "I have to kill my children's father to survive".

title.children: Wife of union boss told private investigator she 'had to kill' estranged husband in recording played to court

image.altText: Cinema audience

props.synopsis: Young people are continuing to bear the brunt of rising interest rates and rent while older Australians are still splashing out, new spending data indicates.

title.children: Younger people now even cutting back on essentials, as older Australians spend up on cruises and restaurants

image.altText: Anthony Albanese smiles while shaking hands with Xi Jinping, whose head is turned away from camera

props.synopsis: Just days before Xi Jinping and Anthony Albanese shook hands at the APEC summit, Australian divers were injured by Chinese sonar. It begs the question, is the on-stage diplomacy all for show?

title.children: China says Australia made an 'irresponsible accusation' over sonar incident. Were the handshakes just for show?

image.altText: HMAS Toowoomba

props.synopsis: China's denial that it sent sonar pulses that left Australian naval divers with minor injuries has been labelled propaganda by the opposition.

title.children: Opposition rejects China's response to sonar injury claim

image.altText: Joel smiling at the camera.

props.synopsis: A second Australian member of a foreigners military unit in Ukraine known as "The Chosen Company" has been killed while fighting against invading Russian forces in the country's east, sources have confirmed to the ABC.

title.children: Second Australian foreign fighter killed battling Russians in Ukraine

image.altText: A view from over of the long bridge, with a section completely destroyed and falling into the water.

props.synopsis: Crossing the Dnipro river has been a major tactical win for Ukraine. But much remains at risk, especially on the eastern bank — and the Russians are well aware of the danger, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Ukraine's successful Dnipro crossing has three major implications for the war

image.altText: A boy and his dad smiling together while on a mountain.

props.synopsis: The South Australian police commissioner makes a public statement for the first time since his son's death, paying tribute to the "force of nature".

title.children: SA Police Commissioner pays heartbreaking tribute to son killed in alleged hit-and-run

image.altText: Four female Chinese international students in front of Sydney Opera House.

props.synopsis: High rents are driving our inflation because of record levels of immigration, and few appear willing to confront the problem. But this is not — and should not — be an argument about multiculturalism, race or diversity, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: The uncomfortable truth about record immigration levels, rents and inflation

image.altText: Two men dressed in black jumpers and carrying M16 rifles walk down an empty street.

props.synopsis: Since the start of the Israel-Gaza war, Jenin in the occupied West Bank has been the major focus of continuous Israeli raids. An Israeli official says they're working to prevent a third front from opening up but a local resident says his neighbours and militants in the camp are angry.

title.children: In Jenin, men patrol the streets and residents say the meaning of life has changed since Hamas's attack

image.altText: A nurse prepares premature babies for transport to Egypt after they were evacuated from Shifa Hospital.

props.synopsis: The newborns had been in north Gaza's Al-Shifa hospital, where several others died after their incubators were knocked out amid a collapse of medical services during Israel's military assault on Gaza City.

title.children: First group of prematurely born babies evacuated from Gaza to Egypt

image.altText: Triple zero number about to be called on a mobile phone.

props.synopsis: A woman tells of a desperate Melbourne roadside rescue as her colleague lay unconscious and she could not get through to emergency operators during the November 8 outage.

title.children: Chris was lucky to survive a heart attack during the Optus outage. His wife is 'disgusted' by the telco's response

image.altText: Police tape cordons off a residential property beneath an overcast sky.

props.synopsis: Police believe the shooting occurred during an altercation between two groups in the town of Moe last night.

title.children: Gippsland shooting leaves 28-year-old with critical injuries, five men arrested

image.altText: A framed photograph of a man smiling

props.synopsis: Adam Bray lost his son Zach in the tragedy that claimed 10 lives in June. He wants a federal taskforce to examine bus safety management, seatbelt use, and regulation to ensure no-one else has to suffer his loss.

title.children: Families to 'demand all day long' for a federal bus safety taskforce after Hunter Valley rollover tragedy

image.altText: Silhouetted people wander among rubble and peer through an exposed entryway to a destroyed house

props.synopsis: A senior Hamas leader says they are "close to reaching a truce agreement" with Israel as the terrorist group delivers its response to Qatari mediators.  Follow live

title.children: Senior Hamas leader says they're nearing 'truce agreement' with Israel

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Senior political leader of Hamas says they're nearing 'truce agreement' with Israel
Acclaimed Palestinian poet reportedly arrested at border checkpoint
Indonesian Hospital attack in 'compliance with international law', Netanyahu adviser says

image.altText: Four kids all wearing white shirts with the face of football player Harley Reid

props.synopsis: Harley Reid is officially heading to West Coast after selecting the Tongala young gun with the first pick of the 2023 AFL Draft, with some surprising draft picks creating some memorable scenes later on.

title.children: Reid becomes an Eagle as home town Tongala celebrates and Gothard, Ryan shocks bring joy

image.altText: A woman sits in front of a computer open to a screen showing purple and green colours

props.synopsis: Staff at the University of Tasmania's business school say they're considering using AI to mark papers, after the uni slashed their time per student.

title.children: 'I'm seriously considering ChatGPT': Uni staff have thousands of words to read when marking student papers

image.altText: A composite image of lightning and heat

props.synopsis: Storms carrying the risk of heavy rain, large hail, and damaging winds are set to hit much of northern and eastern Australia this week while Western Australia bakes under a potential record-breaking November heatwave.

title.children: Week-long spell of extreme heat and storms to hit Australia

image.altText: A man in a suit stares ahead outside a court house with another man in a suit next to him on his right.

props.synopsis: A court has found the police officer son of former senator and NSW premier fabricated evidence with the intent to mislead a judicial tribunal.

title.children: Kristina Keneally's son guilty of fabricating police statement that led to innocent man spending weeks in jail

image.altText: The town sign of Zeehan, on Tasmania's west coast

props.synopsis: Emergency services were called to a park in Zeehan on Monday afternoon where a council worker was found under a mower.

title.children: 'Entire community is in shock' after Tasmanian council worker killed in ride-on mower accident

image.altText: Pat Cummins looks back over his shoulder while holding the World Cup trophy

props.synopsis: The relentless churn of limited-over cricket will see India meet Australia again just days after the Cricket World Cup final, giving neither players, nor fans, time to reflect on and enjoy a thrilling tournament.

title.children: Australia says the Cricket World Cup is still 'the pinnacle' — but 'greed and overkill' sees them play T20 cricket again almost immediately

image.altText: The ASX boards in Sydney

props.synopsis: Mining stocks are driving the Australian share market higher, following a strong performance on Wall Street as Microsoft hit a record high after it recruited OpenAI's former chief executive Sam Altman. Follow live.

title.children: ASX rises as speculation mounts over next Optus CEO, Microsoft hires ex-OpenAI boss Sam Altman

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Are higher interest rates not affecting older Australians who are spending more?
Mining and lithium stocks drive ASX higher
Bullock says surge in migration is just playing 'catch-up' after the pandemic

image.altText: A house for sale in the Brisbane suburb of Stafford with the sale sign in the front yard

props.synopsis: Australian real estate is set for a double-dip downturn, according to a leading analyst, as interest rates finally weigh on property prices and for-sale listings surge.

title.children: The housing boom is tipped to continue in two cities, but most other places are set for price falls

image.altText: A teenage boy sitting with an elderly woman writes on a piece of paper as she looks on.

props.synopsis: Nancy Mullarvey treasures the time she spends with "wonderful" high school students at her Swan Hill aged care home. Their time together is part of a volunteer program with benefits for all involved.

title.children: When Nancy moved into a home at the age of 100, visits from Keenan and his schoolmates made life easier

image.altText: A giant red wave of rock with people nearby.

props.synopsis: A senior Indigenous leader criticises revellers for drinking on the sacred 2.7 billion-year-old rock, saying festival organisers and attendees "need to go read a bit of history".

title.children: Aboriginal elder slams 'disrespectful' festival-goers on Wave Rock

image.altText: Men in suits look concerned as the stand and sit around a table

props.synopsis: The maxi-trial was held in a specially-constructed bunker with video screens anchored to the ceiling so participants could view the proceedings.

title.children: Italian crime syndicate sentenced to combined 2,100 years in prison

image.altText: An elderly man sits in profile wearing a black helmet fitted with sensors. A researcher in a face mask works in the background.

props.synopsis: A new research centre in Hobart is using movie industry technology to track the slightest changes in movement in the hopes of diagnosing neurological diseases before they're noticeable to the human eye.

title.children: Parkinson's can show up in the way you move '15 to 20 years' before a diagnosis — could motion capture tech spot it?

image.altText: Six Qantas planes on Sydney airport tarmac at sunset while a 4x4 car drives past

props.synopsis: At the world's busiest airports, time slots allocated to airlines are an important way for airports to control space. But experts are calling out misuse of the system.

title.children: They call it 'slot hoarding'. It might be the real reason your flight has been cancelled

image.altText: A close up of a brown bat

props.synopsis: Researchers watched hours of video footage of a common bat species doing the deed to discover they use their massive penis like an arm to reproduce via "contact mating" instead of penetration, making them the first-known mammal to use this method.

title.children: 'How is penetration possible?': Scientists unravel the mystery behind tiny bat's oversized penis

image.altText: Annette Kellerman standing on a rock by the ocean with her hands up as if she's about to dive into the water

props.synopsis: Here are six times clothes, and the people who wore or designed them, helped forge the story of our country — for better and worse.

title.children: 'Is there anything this woman couldn't do?' The trailblazing Aussie feminist who shaped our beach fashion
